Subject: Re: [neat] mutation tracking

Interesting. I've been thinking along similar lines, but never done
any act=
ual experiments on it. The problem with the original concept is
that it wou=
ld only single out usually deleterious mutations, by giving
them lower coun=
ts. All other mutations, including largely neutral (and
even long-term neut=
ral) mutations would get high counts, so it would
be hard to single out the=
 best mutations.

Therefore I would definitely go for your variation 1a. Lo=
ok at the
complete mutation history of the best individual of the last
gene=
ration. I think it's a good idea to look at the history, not only
the sums =
over the history, as which mutations are most beneficient
might vary depend=
ing on which generation you are in - e.g., the best
individual might very w=
ell have lots of insert mutations in the
beginning and delete (or global ga=
ussian mutation, if you have real
value) towards the end. For the same reas=
ons, it wouldn't be a very
good idea to limit the history to N generations,=
 as in variation 1b.

The original concept has, as I see it, quite a lot in=
 common with
adaptive self-mutation (or whatever it is called) in Evolution=

Strategies, but variation 1a is more original.

A further idea I have had =
on these lines, but never tried out, is
"Hebbian mutation" - to make insert=
 mutations more likely between
neurons (supposing that what we're evolving =
is neurally networks) that
have correlated activity. The inverse is of cour=
se also possible:
severing connections between unrelated (as determined by =
statistical
correlation) neurons to modularize the network. If we are evolv=
ing
something else than neural networks, we could maybe measure
"relatednes=
s" in some other way.

Julian
On 8/9/05, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...=
> wrote:
>  Hi,
>        suppose in a system you have more than one type of=
 mutation.  They
> might 
>  differ in being inserts vs deletes, or you mig=
ht even consider mutations at
>  different locations to be different types.=

>  
>        OK, now suppose that the population is in mid-evolve and I wa=
nt to
> know 
>  the most constructive ratio of the different types of muta=
tion to 
>  attempt.  How do the following grab you.
>  
>  1) whenever a m=
utation happens, increment a counter corresponding to its 
>  type and also=
 note on the new individual what type of mutation produced it
>  2) wheneve=
r an individual dies, decrement the counter corresponding to the 
>  mutati=
on that produced it
>  3) allocate attempted mutations proportionally to th=
e current state of the 
>  counters
>  
>        As ever, I also generated =
a few variations on the idea:
>  
>  1a) not only store the latest mutation=
s on an individual, but also store 
>  (and count) the total numbers of all=
 mutations found in its ancestry (if 
>  you have sex then you either need =
to count correctly whether a mutation was
>  preserved in the crossover, or=
 else average the numbers from each 
>  parent).  Now you are counting not =
just the last generation of successful 
>  mutations but the whole history =
of successful mutations
>  
>  1b) as 1a but just for the last N generation=
s, not the whole of time
>  
>  1c) rather than incrementing the counters i=
mmediately, do it only after the
>  new individual passes some test (fitnes=
s, longevity, #offspring)
>  
>  2a) rather than decrementing the counters =
when an individual dies, do it 
>  only when one dies too young (assuming y=
ou do not replace the whole 
>  population in every tick)
>  
>  3a) alloca=
te attempted mutations according to the counters but using some 
>  functio=
n "flatter" than the raw counters.  So that rarely successful 
>  mutations=
 become less common, but not too uncommon
>  
>        thoughts anyone?
>  =

>        Ian
